concept.title: Server Group Awareness
concept.shortdesc: Couchbase Server provides the ability to specify that active and corresponding replica vBuckets be placed on servers that are part of a separate rack, or in the case of cloud environments, a separate availability zone.

conbody.note: The Server Group Awareness feature is only available in Couchbase Server Enterprise Edition.
conbody.p: By design, Couchbase Server evenly distributes active and replica vBuckets across the cluster for performance and redundancy. For example, an active vBucket is never placed on the same node as its replica. With Server Group Awareness, you can go one step further by creating logical groupings of Couchbase Server nodes called server groups. When you create server groups, replica vBuckets for servers in one group are automatically distributed to servers in a second group, and vice versa. If one of the servers becomes unavailable, or if an entire server group goes down, data access is retained since the replicas are available on the second server group.

Given that the purpose of Server Group Awareness is to keep the cluster available in the event of large infrastructure failures, it is particularly important that you map server groups to the physical distribution of the nodes. For example, a server group should only include the nodes that are in a single server rack, or in the case of cloud deployments, a single availability zone. That way, if the server rack or availability zone becomes unavailable due to a power or network failure, the entire server group can fail over as a unit without the need to rebalance.

When Server Group Awareness becomes active, the cluster automatically rebalances the replica vBuckets to be evenly distributed between server groups. If an imbalance occurs where there is an unequal number of nodes in one server group, the rebalance operation performs a "best effort" of evenly distributing the replica vBuckets across the cluster.

p.b: General notes about Server Group Awareness:

ul.li: Server Group Awareness only applies to the Data Service.

When you initialize a new Couchbase Server cluster, the first node is automatically placed in a server group named Group 1. Server Group Awareness will automatically enable once you add a second server group that contains at least one node.
There is no limit on the number of server groups that can be created.

section.title: Distribution of vBuckets and Replica vBuckets
section.p: The following example shows how the Server Group Awareness functionality implements replica vBuckets to provide redundancy. In this example, the cluster is made up of eight nodes that are evenly distributed into two server groups (four nodes in each server group). Since there is an equal number of nodes in each server group, the cluster is balanced, which guarantees that replica vBuckets for one server group are on a different server group.
The following diagram shows the two server groups - Rack #1 and Rack #2 - with each group containing four nodes.

ul.li: Group 1 servers have their active vBuckets and replica vBuckets from Group 2.
Group 2 servers have their active vBuckets and replica vBuckets from Group 1.

section.title: Distribution with Additional Server
section.p: The following example shows how Server Group Awareness functionality implements replica vBuckets when an imbalance is caused by an additional server being added to one server group. In this example, an additional server (Server 9) is added to one of the server groups (Group 1). An imbalance occurs because one server group has more servers than the other server group. In this case, the rebalance operation performs a "best effort" of evenly distributing the replica vBuckets of the additional server across the nodes on all of the racks in the cluster.

p.note: If the cluster becomes imbalanced, you should add servers to balance the cluster. For optimal Server Group Awareness functionality, a balanced cluster is recommended.

section.p: The following diagram shows the two server groups - Rack #1 and Rack #2 - where one group has five nodes and the other group has four nodes.

ul.li: Group 1 servers have their active vBuckets and replica vBuckets from Group 2.
Group 1 Servers 1 - 4 also have replica vBuckets for Server 9.
Group 2 servers have their active vBuckets and replica vBuckets from Group 1 including the replica vBuckets from Server 9 in Group 1.

section.title: Distribution with Unavailable Server
section.p: The following example shows how Server Group Awareness functionality implements replica vBuckets when an imbalance is caused by a server being removed or becoming unavailable in a server group. In this example, a server (Server 2) is unavailable to a server group (Group 1). An imbalance occurs because one server group has fewer servers than the other server group. In this case, the rebalance operation performs a "best effort" of evenly distributing the replica vBuckets of the additional server across the nodes on all of the racks in the cluster
section.note: If the cluster becomes imbalanced, you should add servers to balance the cluster. For optimal Server Group Awareness functionality, a balanced cluster is recommended.
section.p: The following diagram shows the loss of a server resulting in an imbalance. In this case, Server 2 (from Group 1) becomes unavailable. The replica vBuckets for Server 2 in Group 2 become enabled and rebalancing occurs.

ul.li: Group 1 servers have their active vBuckets and replica vBuckets from Group 2.
Group 2 servers have their active vBuckets and replica vBuckets from Group 1.
Group 2 server activates the replica vBuckets for Server 2 in Group 1.
